title: Have you ever felt like you can't forgive someone? - Quora

The …first he messaged today the first reply I gave “ tum thiik ho ..” and the next and the next me and my anger of all the days I cried ..I felt down were striked to my mind . Absolutely. I can think of several times in my life where someone hurt me and I really didn’t think I would ever be able to forgive them. The hardest was when I lost a friend in a school shooting. The boy who took her life killed himself as well. I had no idea how to forgive him, both because I was in so much pain and because I would never be able to speak with him directly. It took me three years to finally forgive him. I wish there had been some foolproof formula for forgiveness I could have followed, but I’ve found forgiveness and healing look different every time. I had to come to an understanding that he was a broken and hurting human just like the rest of us. That of course does not condone his actions, but being able to see him as human helped me find the strength to forgive him. I’m so glad I did! Although he’ll never know I’ve forgiven him it has made such a big difference in my own life. I’m no longer carrying around that burden of anger and bitterness. Forgiveness isn’t easy but I’ve found it really is so important. What about you friend? Has there ever been someone you didn’t think you could forgive?

About 16 years ago there was a woman who hurt me beyond years and I forgave her, then I un-forgave, her. I was back and forth like that over and over again. I knew I needed to forgive her, but I just wasn’t able to make it stick. I prayed many times for God to help me forgive her. At that time one of my sons was a drug addict and it’s hell to go through that as a parent. Her son was also an addict. So one day I was leaving somewhere and she was arriving and there was no way to avoid her without being extremely obvious. So I greeted her and hugged her. When I hugged her, instead of anger, my heart was filled with love and compassion, because I knew what she was living through with her son. I felt the weight of the unforgiveness lift off my shoulders. It was so wonderful to finally be able to forgive her. That was about 6 years ago and the forgiveness stuck.

For sure. My father and the three women who decided to divorce me come to mind. At 18 when I was considering suicide, I “saw the light” to let go of all my condemning others (and myself) and stop putting deep trust in others. So I made an agreement with Jesus to trust in God (the metaphor for virtue and ideal love) and not in any people or even myself. Over the next few years I learned how to forgive my father and see he was doing nothing more than “what he was capable of” in the best way “he knew” how to. It made no difference if it hurt me and caused me to hate him….those were my responses, not likely his intentions at the time. So inside of me, I forgave him and also myself for having hated him. Later with my wives, I was already practiced in forgiving but I admit that my first wife (and her intense anger) was even harder for me to forgive. But I saw that condemning and hate hurt me, not her. I saw I was buying what she was selling (anger and hate) and I decided I would not buy that. So I decided I’d care about her wellbeing (and still do now, 30 years later). Later she called and apologized for her anger and hate in the marriage and divorce. She said she was in a 12 step program to shed her hate since she was sexually abused by her father and uncle as a child and grew to distrust all men. I told her I had forgiven her. So it became a sad pattern that I repeated twice more by marrying women who hated their fathers (one said she didn’t but during the divorce she admitted she did). Hope my reply helps someone.

Yes. I had helped a younger engineer working in my division in developing his career by guiding him every step of the way. I tried my best to be his mentor, enhancing his capabilities and discouraging his negative aspects. Later, when I started my own company, I took him in, and gave him independent responsibility to handle sales work. From that point, he started disappearing for days, claiming to be busy with sales work. When he didn't bring any order for 3 months, I was surprised but only gave him a warning. When he could not get orders for the next quarter too, I told him that I might have to consider terminating him, if he didn't show good performance within the next couple of months. A few weeks later, I was shocked to get information through a third party that my guy was trying to get orders for my competitor, while still working for me. I collected necessary evidence and confronted him. Initially he didn't admit his wrongdoing, but he had to admit it when I brought up the evidence. I could not forgive him for betraying my trust, after I had mentored him for over 3 years. I sacked him right away and told him not to meet me again.

Frequently. I still feel negative for several circumstances. My first ex who said he'd marry me, but then broke up with me after 4 years of this vain promise, my second ex who made it seem he cared a lot for me but got bored, my ex-friends who ghosted on me… Forgiveness is the hardest thing to do, because we don't know for certain how to heal psychological hurt. We have better knowledge of healing physical pain, if it's possible. But where do we put the bandage for our mind?

But it's been over a year now since she delt me such a shit hand and every time I check in on her existence on the net I notice she's ruining her own life more than I ever could anyways. Cheating on her boyfriend and selling her body, failing school, not being able to hold a job, probably on drugs again I'm assuming from her income in and out ratio. So I'm actually slowly getting over thoughts of malice since she's so ept at destroying her own life.

Yep! My father left when I was 8 then came back when I was 18. I am now 26 and still hold resentment towards him. He doesn’t even have a good reason to why he left and stayed gone. He’s a fucking idiot, so I don’t expect much from him. *shrugs* Some people are just fucking dumb and keep repeating history. Ugh.

Yes, several times in my life with different people. But one can find a place in one’s heart where forgiveness resides, even if the memory remains. It is good to forgive, just do not forget the lesson learned.
Too much luggage to carry to the forgiveness train. So my answer is no. I not a saint, and I’m not God.
